question: Is higher exposure to fine particulate matter (PM2.5) associated with increased prevalence of anxiety symptoms? Answer with Yes or No.

content.source_1: Significantly increased odds of high anxiety symptoms were observed with higher exposure to PM2.5 for multiple averaging periods (for example, odds ratio per 10 μg/m(3) increase in prior one month average PM2.5: 1.12, 95% confidence interval 1.06 to 1.19; in prior 12 month average PM2.5: 1.15, 1.06 to 1.26).
content.source_2: Using a time-stratified case-crossover design controlling for meteorology and day-of-week, we found no elevation in anxiety prevalence with higher PM2.5; the odds ratio per 10 μg/m3 increase in the prior 1-month average was 0.99 (95% CI, 0.93–1.05) and for the prior 12-month average was 1.00 (0.94–1.07).
content.source_3: CONCLUSIONS Exposure to fine particulate matter (PM2.5) was associated with high symptoms of anxiety, with more recent exposures potentially more relevant than more distant exposures.
content.source_4: Among a cohort of middle-aged urban men followed for five years, long-term ambient PM2.5 showed an inverse association with the prevalence of clinically significant anxiety (adjusted odds ratio per 10 μg/m3 = 0.91; 95% CI, 0.84–0.99), and short-term averages were likewise non-significant.
